string.text: Alife Overhaul - Default (1x)
Alife Overhaul - Fast (2x)
Alife Overhaul - Rapid (5x)
Alife Overhaul - Test (10x)
Use old auto-capture method
When this option is enabled, autocapture will occur using the old method, where a squad is spawned on top of your position for free once the capture time has elapsed.
Hide lair smart terrains
When enabled, the PDA will not display icons for smart terrains with no useful properties, such as purely mutant lair terrains.
Goodwill on kill: base

When you kill an enemy, you will be granted this amount of goodwill with your faction plus a bonus based on the victim's rank and the multiplier: goodwill = base + (enemy rank * rank multiplier). Loners receive 50% of this value.
Goodwill on kill: enemy rank multiplier
This setting affects the bonus amount of faction goodwill granted on kill based on the victim's rank. The goodwill gained is equal to: goodwill = base + (enemy rank * rank multiplier)
Max monster squads per level (laboratories)
This setting is the same as the "max monster squads per level" setting, but applies for all underground and laboratory levels.
Contested terrains strain relations

When this setting is enabled, two neutral factions contesting a single point will become upset with each other if one of them 'steals' the location from the other. This puts pressure on neutral factions that share a border. Works best with a relations addon, or lowered death_value in dynamic_faction_relations.ltx
Rare mutant % chance (Southern Zone)
The percent chance that a mutant spawn in military warehouses/dead city/truck cemetery and south will be a rare mutant (controller, chimera, etc). Default: 3
Rare mutant % chance (Northern Zone)
The percent chance that a mutant spawn in Limansk/red forest/radar and north will be a rare mutant (controller, chimera, etc). Default: 10
Rare mutant % chance (Laboratories)
The percent chance that a mutant spawn in a laboratory will be a rare mutant (controller, chimera, etc). Default: 50
Disincentivise Attacks on Main Bases

When this setting is enabled, all factions will no longer attack main bases of other factions unless they have no other available target. For example, the Freedom Base will no longer send an attack to the Duty Base at the Bar until no other capturable locations exist within linked-level distance (Army Warehouses, Dead City, Red Forest, Truck Cemetery). Enable this setting if you want to ensure that unique NPCs don't die from early invasions. DISABLE this setting when using randomized starting locations!
Offline Combat Distance (Warfare ONLY)
Maximum distance, in meters, that offline squads will engage in offline combat when "Full" offline combat is used. Default: 50
Automate overflow squad handling during manual control

Typically, when manual faction control is disabled, overflow squads (i.e. squads surpassing the smart terrain limit) are automatically re-assigned. When manual faction control is enabled, overflow squads are no longer handled automatically. Toggling this setting on restores the automated handling of these squads while preserving the rest of the manual faction control functionality.
Extra fog of war for loner players

When this setting is active, players playing as 'free stalkers' will not be able to see loner squads or outposts outside of their fog of war distance unless they use PDA v2 or PDA v3. This is similar to non-Warfare vision. If this setting is disabled, bases and squads of free stalkers will be visible even with PDA v1. This setting is only functional when fog of war is enabled.
Distance-based combat multiplier
Enable distance-based combat effectiveness multipliers. Squads perform better when fighting near friendly strategic locations like bases, resources, territory, and lairs.
Distance combat min multiplier
The minimum combat effectiveness multiplier applied when squads are far from any friendly strategic locations. This is the baseline combat strength used at maximum distance.
Distance combat max multiplier (base)
Maximum combat effectiveness multiplier when near friendly bases. Bases provide the strongest strategic support and highest combat bonus.
Distance combat max multiplier (resource)
Maximum combat effectiveness multiplier when near friendly resource points. Resources provide moderate support through supplies and equipment.
Distance combat max multiplier (territory)
Maximum combat effectiveness multiplier when near friendly territory. Controlled territory provides basic support through familiar terrain.
Distance combat max multiplier (lair)
Maximum combat effectiveness multiplier when near friendly lairs.
Distance combat max distance
The maximum distance at which distance-based combat multipliers are calculated. Squads beyond this distance from friendly strategic locations receive the minimum multiplier.
Use new resurgence logic

When enabled, uses improved emergency resurrection system for extinct factions. Creates powerful squads that target the closest enemy/empty strategic locations when a faction has zero bases. When disabled, uses the original random resurgence system.
Squad quality depends on base count (instead of resources)

Normally, a faction's squad quality is calculated based on the number of resources it holds. When this option is selected, this faction's squad quality will be calculated based on number of held bases instead. Primarily meant to be used for factions that don't care about resources (ex: army).

Squad power in offline combat is multiplied by this amount. If this is set to 2, for instance, squads that are a part of this faction will deal twice as much damage as typical squads in offline combat.

The overall aggression and offensive responsiveness of a faction. More aggressive factions will send squads to capture empty targets sooner, add additional targets to each of their bases faster, and plan invasions to those targets sooner. Higher aggression will also cause a faction to prioritize carrying out invasion plans sooner by sending squads from nearby bases, whereas less aggressive factions will be more content to keep their squads at their current locations.

The chance that a faction will send out invasion forces or send patrol squads anywhere during the night time. Night time is considered as between the hours of 8:00pm and 6:00am, or 20:00 and 6:00. Whether a smart terrain can be active during nighttime is decided once per night per smart terrain. For free stalker and ecologist factions, this sets the likelihood for a squad to visit another resource point instead of going back to base for the night.

This is how many in-game minutes it takes for a faction to spawn a squad from a base point if they own only one base. As your faction gains more bases, each individual base will have a slightly longer spawn time approaching that of the maximum respawn time. The actual respawn time of a given base is linearly interpolated based on the min/max respawn values and the percentage of bases in the Zone you control.

This is how many in-game minutes it takes for a faction to spawn a squad from a base point if they own all the bases in the Zone. As your faction gains more bases, each individual base will have a slightly longer spawn time approaching that of the maximum respawn time. The actual respawn time of a given base is linearly interpolated based on the min/max respawn values and the percentage of bases in the Zone you control. For reference, there are roughly 80 base points in the Zone.

The minimum invasion size factor. A random number between the minimum and maximum invasion size factors is multiplied by the calculated invasion size to give the number of squads that a base will invade with. The size of the invasion force is calculated using the max capacity of the target location, reinforcement potential of any enemy locations near the target, the relative difference in squad power between the factions, and these min/max factors. The invasion size cannot be more than twice the maximum capacity of the origin base (ex: if a base with max capacity of 2 plans to invade a target with max capacity of 5, the invasion can be no larger than 4 squads). If this limitation prevents a small base from planning an adequate invasion, that base will instead contribute squads to a larger nearby base's invasion force.

The maximum invasion size factor. A random number between the minimum and maximum invasion size factors is multiplied by the calculated invasion size to give the number of squads that a base will invade with. The size of the invasion force is calculated using the max capacity of the target location, reinforcement potential of any enemy locations near the target, the relative difference in squad power between the factions, and these min/max factors. The invasion size cannot be more than twice the maximum capacity of the origin base (ex: if a base with max capacity of 2 plans to invade a target with max capacity of 5, the invasion can be no larger than 4 squads). If this limitation prevents a small base from planning an adequate invasion, that base will instead contribute squads to a larger nearby base's invasion force. This value is also used for defense to determine the desired power factor versus incoming enemy forces: a value of 1.5 means that the defending base will try to call reinforcements to get a power advantage 1.5x that of the enemy invasion.
The minimum patrol squad population factor. When a faction owns no bases, each base would (theoretically since they don't own any) have min_patrol_squads * max_population amount of patrol squads.
The maximum patrol squad population factor. When a faction owns every base, each base will have max_patrol_squads * max_population amount of patrol squads.

This is how many in-game minutes it takes for a faction to spawn a patrol squad from a base point if they own only one base. As your faction gains more bases, each individual base will have a slightly longer patrol spawn time approaching that of the maximum patrol respawn time. The actual patrol respawn time of a given base is linearly interpolated based on the min/max patrol respawn values and the percentage of bases in the Zone you control.

This is how many in-game minutes it takes for a faction to spawn a patrol squad from a base point if they own every base in the Zone. As your faction gains more bases, each individual base will have a slightly longer patrol spawn time approaching that of the maximum patrol respawn time. The actual patrol respawn time of a given base is linearly interpolated based on the min/max patrol respawn values and the percentage of bases in the Zone you control. For reference, there are roughly 80 bases in the Zone.

When a base is looking for a new target for a patrol squad, and if there is an enemy patrol squad on the current level or a linked level, this is the chance that the base will assign the enemy patrol squad as a target; if the squad is not assigned an enemy patrol squad as a target then it will be assigned a territory/lair point near the base to patrol as usual.
The minimum amount of time a patrol squad will wait at a territory/lair point. Night activity chance will also affect whether or not they are sent to a new point.
The maximum amount of time a patrol squad will wait at a territory/lair point. Night activity chance will also affect whether or not they are sent to a new point.
Resurgence Chance

When a faction owns zero bases, they are considered 'defeated'. Once defeated, they have a chance for a 'resurgence', where a large attack force appears in an attempt to capture a random enemy base on the map. The timer for this attack depends on the minimum and maximum resurgence times. Additionally, there is a chance that the resurgence attempt will be skipped over: a resurgence chance of 50 will skip half of all resurgence attempts, while a resurgence chance of 0 will always skip attempts (as if the faction is permanently defeated).
When enabled, every squad for this faction will have a random number of NPCs between min_random_squad_count and max_random_squad_count.
When random_squad_count is enabled, this is the minimum number of NPCs a squad will have for this faction.
When random_squad_count is enabled, this is the maximum number of NPCs a squad will have for this faction.

Random patrols are squads that periodically target locations all over. They spawn preferentially on a faction's owned points, otherwise they can spawn anywhere in the Zone. Their targeting is influenced by your faction's priorities for base/resource/territory/levels. They can be temporarily commanded by you to move to certain points, but will eventually pick their own target after some amount of idle time.
This is the absolute maximum amount of random patrols a faction can have at once.
The lowest possible time for a new random patrol of this faction to spawn. The actual spawn time is randomly chosen between this number and the maximum random patrol time.
The highest possible time for a new random patrol of this faction to spawn. The actual spawn time is randomly chosen between this number and the minimum random patrol time.
The chance that an invasion will depart during the current process_targets update. This is called every 1 to 5 in-game minutes.
How much the faction prioritises bases.
How much the faction prioritises resource points.

How much a base prioritises points that are flagged for their owning faction in the gamedata/configs/misc/simulation_objects_props.ltx file. For instance if Clear Sky is looking at a territory point, it will increase the priority for a point by 2 if in that file the point has csky = 1 defined for it.
If a base is being targeted by another base, it will add this much priority to it in order to attempt to counter the invasion.
How much a base prioritises points which have less powerful squads present.
How much a base prioritises points which have more powerful squads present.
How much a base prioritises points which are on the same level as itself.

The maximum possible number of targets a base can have at once. Bases will add extra targets beyond their minimum number of targets based on their faction aggression setting. Higher faction aggressions cause bases to add targets faster. This setting should be kept at or above the minimum smart targets per base.
Minimum smart targets per base
A base will always target at least this many locations. The base will send squads to empty targets, or invade hostile targets.
How many resource points are added to a faction's resource count. This can be negative. Higher numbers cause stronger squads to spawn.
How many bases are added to a faction's owned base count. This can be negative. Higher numbers cause longer base respawn times, approaching the value set by maximum respawn time.
